results.title: Penguins in Your Fridge? These 7-Year-Olds Have Climate Solutions.

results.title: Black Bear Kills Arizona Man in ‘Highly Uncommon’ Attack
results.abstract: A 66-year-old man was having a morning coffee when a male black bear dragged him down an embankment. A neighbor shot and killed the animal, officials said.

media.caption: A 66-year-old man was fatally attacked on Friday by a male black bear near Prescott, Ariz., the authorities said.

results.adx_keywords: Espionage and Intelligence Services;Informers;United States Politics and Government;Political Prisoners;Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;audio-neutral-informative;audio-negative-sad;Central Intelligence Agency;Afghanistan;China;Iran;Pakistan;Russia
results.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman
results.title: Captured, Killed or Compromised: C.I.A. Admits to Losing Dozens of Informants
results.abstract: Counterintelligence officials said in a top secret cable to all stations and bases around the world that too many of the people it recruits from other countries to spy for the U.S. are being lost.

media.caption: Members of the Taliban at the former C.I.A. Eagle Base in Kabul in September. The agency has devoted much of its attention for the last two decades to terrorist threats and the conflicts in Afghanistan, Iraq and Syria, but improving intelligence collection on adversaries like China and Russia is once again a centerpiece of its agenda.
media.copyright: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

results.title: Juneteenth: The History of a Holiday
results.abstract: On June 19, 1865, enslaved African Americans in Texas were told they were free. A century and a half later, people across the U.S. continue to celebrate the day, which is now a federal holiday.

media.caption: A Juneteenth celebration in Galveston, Texas, last year. The holiday traces its roots to the city.
